Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Story: The lunch rush at the grocery store was in full swing, and I was moving as fast as I could behind the register, scanning items and smiling at each customer. My manager had reminded me just that morning to keep the line moving and stay cheerful, no matter how hectic things got. As I handed change to a woman with a toddler tugging at her sleeve, I caught sight of my younger brother through the big front window. He was at the edge of the parking lot, skateboard in hand, eyeing the steep, cracked ramp that led down to the loading dock. I knew he’d been practicing a new trick, and I also knew how dangerous that ramp was. My parents always said I was supposed to look out for him, make sure he didn’t get hurt. But the line of customers stretched past the magazine rack, and I could feel their impatience. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on the next order, torn between the expectation to be the reliable, friendly cashier and the older sibling who was supposed to keep my brother safe.
